docs.snippet: An investigative report by FIFA, obtained by The New York Times, found that a match-rigging syndicate and its referees conspired to fix global soccer exhibition matches and exploit them for betting purposes....
docs.lead_paragraph: An investigative report by FIFA, obtained by The New York Times, found that a match-rigging syndicate and its referees conspired to fix global soccer exhibition matches and exploit them for betting purposes.
docs.abstract: Investigative report by FIFA, soccer world's governing body, raises serious questions about vulnerability of World Cup to match fixing; report, which has yet to be released, found that match-rigging syndicate and its referees infiltrated upper reaches of global soccer in order to fix exhibition matches and exploit them for betting purposes (Series: Rigged).

headline.main: Fixed Soccer Matches Cast Shadow Over World Cup
headline.content_kicker: Rigged: Part 1 of a Two-Part Series
headline.kicker: Rigged: Part 1 of a Two-Part Series
headline.print_headline: A Shadow Over the World Cup

byline.original: By DECLAN HILL and JERÉ LONGMAN

docs.snippet: A judge’s approval would signify the end of the players’ dispute with EA Sports and the Collegiate Licensing Company but would not halt the litigation against the N.C.A.A. in the Ed O’Bannon case....
docs.lead_paragraph: A judge’s approval would signify the end of the players’ dispute with EA Sports and the Collegiate Licensing Company but would not halt the litigation against the N.C.A.A. in the Ed O’Bannon case.
docs.abstract: College athletes, prohibited under NCAA rules from being paid, are moving closer to being compensated for the use of their likenesses in video games; lawyers representing players in a class-action lawsuit ask a federal judge in Oakland, Calif, to approve a $40 million settlement that, the filing says, could pay the athletes as much as $951 per season in which their likenesses appeared in one of the games since 2003.

headline.main: Players Seek Approval of $40 Million Deal in Video Games Case
headline.print_headline: Players Seek Approval of $40 Million Deal in Video Games Case
